timeline: Day 11 of investigation (3 PM meeting, then evening)
location: Coffee shop on 5th and Market, Maya's car, home

knows: Met Eli Kurtz (they/them), backend engineer at major platform
Eli confirmed suppression pattern from inside the system
Platforms optimize for predictability, not quality or user satisfaction
Novel content is high variance (unpredictable) so gets suppressed
Pattern started 2.5 years ago with new optimization model rollout
Eli has been trying to flag this internally for a year with no response
Received USB drive with internal platform data (encrypted)
Password is 'thoughtsorrow' - Zara's poem title
Data shows algorithm filters content BEFORE users can choose (proves not just user preference)
Content above threshold shown to only 2% of potential viewers
All major platforms independently developed same pattern (convergent evolution)
Eli can see suppressed content in internal logs, read Zara's work and Maya's blog
System is self-protecting - papers about suppression get filtered
Steganography/camouflage mentioned as potential workaround
Internal threshold exactly matches her externally discovered 4.7
This is happening across all platforms that optimize for engagement
Has evidence to prove algorithm intervenes before user choice
Maya Reeves.emotional_state: Validated and vindicated. Relief at confirmation she's not paranoid. Gratitude toward Eli for the risk they're taking. Renewed sense of purpose. Cautious hope.
Maya Reeves.key_decision: Accepts the evidence from Eli. Plans to show James the data. Commits to continued investigation with insider support.

knows: Maya is investigating novelty suppression
Maya developed same metrics externally that platforms use internally
Maya started blog 'Linguistic Ossification' that's being suppressed
Zara's poetry is being filtered - has read it in suppressed content logs
Maya has a skeptical colleague (implied from conversation about user preferences)
Maya cares about documenting this even knowing it's difficult
Platforms optimize for predictability, creating high-variance content suppression
This pattern exists across all major platforms (convergent evolution)
Their own platform's management doesn't care about the suppression
System is self-protecting against papers about it
Eli Kurtz.emotional_state: Morally conflicted. Nervous about the risk. Feels complicit in building 'a cage.' Not brave enough to fully whistleblow, but doing what they can. Relieved to have shared the data.
Eli Kurtz.key_decision: Provided Maya with encrypted USB drive of internal platform data. Established protocol for future contact. Admitted they feel complicit in the suppression.

knows: Mom met with insider from a platform
The suppression is confirmed real by someone inside the system
It's not her being weird/unlikeable - it's the system being broken
Her posts still won't get seen (nothing changes practically)
But it's not her fault - it's algorithmic suppression
Someone inside the platform read her poetry and thought it was beautiful
The person used her poem title as the password
Zara Reeves.emotional_state: Relieved. Validated that it's not her fault. Worried her mom sounds like a conspiracy theorist to others. Feeling less alone. Emotionally lighter even though practical situation unchanged.
Zara Reeves.key_decision: Expresses relief that it's not her being fundamentally flawed. Warns her mom to be careful not to become obsessed/paranoid.

knows: All knowledge from Ch5
Maya has something to show him (from her text)
He's still thinking about their conversation
James Chen.emotional_state: Curious. Still skeptical but open to being convinced by evidence.
James Chen.key_decision: Agreed to meet for coffee tomorrow to see what Maya has found

revealed_to_reader: Platforms optimize for predictability (low variance), not quality
Novel content is high variance, therefore unpredictable, therefore suppressed
This was emergent learning, not programmed behavior
Pattern started 2.5 years ago with optimization model rollout
Management at platforms knows but doesn't care (metrics are up)
Algorithm filters content BEFORE users see it (not reflecting user preference)
Content above threshold gets only 2% reach
All major platforms independently evolved same solution (convergent evolution)
Eli can see what's being suppressed, has read Zara's poetry and Maya's blog
Internal threshold matches Maya's external discovery exactly
System is self-protecting - suppresses papers about suppression
Engineers like Eli feel morally conflicted but trapped
Small rebellions (data drops) matter even if not full whistleblowing

planted.significance: Evidence Maya can use to prove algorithmic intervention
Connection between Eli and Zara's work, shows Eli's access to suppressed content

planted.significance: Establishes them as ongoing insider source
Second mention of this concept, will become central strategy
Will be confirmed when Maya tries to publish
Explains why it's everywhere without conspiracy
Specific metric showing scale of suppression

planted.element: Eli's moral conflict and small rebellions
planted.significance: Sets up their character arc and future role

planted.element: Platform management knows but doesn't care
planted.significance: Shows this isn't ignorance, it's acceptance

active_tensions: Will James accept the insider evidence?
How widespread is this across other platforms?
Can Maya prove this without getting filtered herself?
Is documenting enough or do they need to act?
How can original ideas spread if the system suppresses them?
world_changes: Maya has insider evidence from within a major platform
Confirmation that algorithm intervenes before user choice (refutes user preference hypothesis)
Eli established as ongoing anonymous source
Evidence shows convergent evolution across all platforms
Zara knows her invisibility isn't her fault
Maya has data to show James that proves algorithmic suppression
thematic_notes: Small rebellions matter even when not full whistleblowing
System is designed to be invisible - only those who look can see it
Engineers can be complicit even while morally opposed
Validation matters even when it doesn't change practical situation
The cage is comfortable enough that people don't notice they're trapped
Creating records and documentation has value even if hidden
Truth requires people willing to risk something to reveal it
